body:
On Linux at least. It's still not available on Windows yet, and if you want it to happen for Mac someone else will have to do it, because I don't have a Mac.

I added the basic mod functions, which should suffice for most mods. For more details check [the docs on github](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/tree/master/Docs/mods). It still needs some work, for instance if a mod needs to remove or alter something in the core game, that is currently not possible. I don't know how I'm going to handle that, maybe set flags for different portions of code that can be toggled by mods. That would require conflict/compatibility testing to make sure one mod doesn't enable something while another disables it. But you can actually add stuff to the game now!

If you're interested in creating mods for VoxelPlanet, [the docs](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/tree/master/Docs/mods) should explain what you need to know. One thing I forgot to add though is that the actual game should be compiled with the `-rdynamic` flag or whatever your compiler's equivalent to that is, so make sure you do that, otherwise your mods won't be able to access variables and functions from the game. There are two example mods in the github repo, so if you're confused use them as a baseline.
body_html:
On Linux at least. It's still not available on Windows yet, and if you want it to happen for Mac someone else will have to do it, because I don't have a Mac.

I added the basic mod functions, which should suffice for most mods. For more details check the docs on github. It still needs some work, for instance if a mod needs to remove or alter something in the core game, that is currently not possible. I don't know how I'm going to handle that, maybe set flags for different portions of code that can be toggled by mods. That would require conflict/compatibility testing to make sure one mod doesn't enable something while another disables it. But you can actually add stuff to the game now!

If you're interested in creating mods for VoxelPlanet, the docs should explain what you need to know. One thing I forgot to add though is that the actual game should be compiled with the -rdynamic flag or whatever your compiler's equivalent to that is, so make sure you do that, otherwise your mods won't be able to access variables and functions from the game. There are two example mods in the github repo, so if you're confused use them as a baseline.

body:
As the owner and creator of this guild and /r/EverythingFoxes, I'm not that great of a foxposter. Why? Because I struggle to find any new quality content related to foxes.

However, I've noticed that quite a few others are doing so rather easily. My guess is that they know of some obscure fox websites that you can't really discover unless someone happens to mention it to you. Unfortunately, these people almost always reupload what they find to gfycat, imgur, or i.ruqqus and i.redd.it, and link to that instead, so you can't find the source where they're getting all this content from. My only sources atm are reddit, google, imgur, gfycat, and hourly flops. Those are great for finding long-time popular reposts, but all except the latter are terrible for discovering *new* (quality) content. (Hourly flops is good, but people are clearly getting their content from many more sources than just that, and hourly flops only has pics, no videos/gifs).

So, those of you who find a bunch of new fox pics and gifs all the time, what gives? Where are you getting them from, and where do you find them at?

Edit: Foxposters, show yourselves! I'm pinning this post so people who come to this guild in the future will see it and can find your foxy content sources.

Edit 2: Someone just gave me a bunch of sources:

* [Hourly Fops](https://t.me/HourlyFops)
* [Fennec Friends](https://t.me/FennecFriends)
* [RedTaily](https://t.me/redtaily)
* [Foxposting](https://t.me/foxposting)
* [coolfoxaccount](https://twitter.com/CoolFoxAccount)
* [hourlyFox](https://twitter.com/hourlyFox)
* https://foxrudor.de/
* https://fox-info.net/
* [Juniper](https://www.youtube.com/c/JuniperFox/videos)
* [Alice the Fox](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCiEFbQHfI-iiez0NBr6ZV1g)
* [SaveAFox](https://www.youtube.com/c/SaveAFox)
* [Loki the Red Fox](https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCvbRv7guDemGXy12jyk4ZzA)

Apparently following these on telegram/twitter will cause the algorithms to find more of them and suggest them to you, so that's how these people always manage to discover these niche accounts/websites.

Edit 2: Someone just gave me a bunch of sources:

body:
I started my first programming about 8 years ago in Java. It didn't get serious until about 4 years ago however, and a year after that I started C and C++.

I find it fun and enjoyable building things. Needless to say though, as much as I like it and do it a lot, I fucking suck, like I do at pretty much everything in life.

All the people I've met in programming channels on this site, discord, github, etc could finish even my biggest projects, which took me weeks, in a day or even mere hours, by putting in about half as much effort. Most people can finish several semi-professional projects in a month, albeit small, and each one takes them only a few hours to make, and a few days to *finish*, entirely by themselves. They can also take a few months to build very complex applications, by themselves. I have *never* made anything even remotely releasable in my whole life, just a bunch of shit that only I can use, and it always has a ton of problems that I can never figure out and every one of my solutions is half-baked. In fact, most of my intended projects never even end up being able to execute at all, let alone become mature. I run into so many problems that I have probably never written more than 100 lines in a day, even though most people can do thousands. Everything I do is just out of boredom too, I can't even write a small program that's actually useful in any way. In a nutshell, "hello world" is still the only thing I can make that's fully in working order.

Most devs also seem to know just about every single language in existence, no sweat. Not just a "I kinda know how to use it" deal, an actual rich understanding of all of them, knowing all the nooks and crannies of each one. Me? I know Java, C, and C++. And even those I don't have a particularly good understanding of, just enough to get things done. I have to google even very basic things that even people who don't use those as their main language would know about. I am also completely unable to make anything for platforms other than the one I'm currently using. No raspberry pi, no android, no web apps, nothing. I can't use CMake or anything either, because I'm still too busy figuring out everything else after so many years.

Wtf is wrong with me? Why am I so bad?

body:
This *is* a repost but I posted the last one last night, and I wanted to hit the opposite timezones as well to get a wide range of answers. So if you already saw this post, I apologize, and you can ignore it.

---

I started my first programming about 8 years ago in Java. It didn't get serious until about 4 years ago however, and a year after that I started C and C++.

I find it fun and enjoyable building things. Needless to say though, as much as I like it and do it a lot, I fucking suck, like I do at pretty much everything in life.

All the people I've met in programming channels on this site, discord, github, etc could finish even my biggest projects, which took me weeks, in a day or even mere hours, by putting in about half as much effort. Most people can finish several semi-professional projects in a month, albeit small, and each one takes them only a few hours to make, and a few days to *finish*, entirely by themselves. They can also take a few months to build very complex applications, by themselves. I have *never* made anything even remotely releasable in my whole life, just a bunch of shit that only I can use, and it always has a ton of problems that I can never figure out and every one of my solutions is half-baked. In fact, most of my intended projects never even end up being able to execute at all, let alone become mature. I run into so many problems that I have probably never written more than 100 lines in a day, even though most people can do thousands. Everything I do is just out of boredom too, I can't even write a small program that's actually useful in any way. In a nutshell, "hello world" is still the only thing I can make that's fully in working order.

Most devs also seem to know just about every single language in existence, no sweat. Not just a "I kinda know how to use it" deal, an actual rich understanding of all of them, knowing all the nooks and crannies of each one. Me? I know Java, C, and C++. And even those I don't have a particularly good understanding of, just enough to get things done. I have to google even very basic things that even people who don't use those as their main language would know about. I am also completely unable to make anything for platforms other than the one I'm currently using. No raspberry pi, no android, no web apps, nothing. I can't use CMake or anything either, because I'm still too busy figuring out everything else after so many years.

Wtf is wrong with me? Why am I so bad?

---

Some people in my last post weren't believing me, so here is an example of some devs who frequently make simple, small projects that should be trivial to complete. These are the things I cannot do, even though they're so small and simple. In fact I can not even come close, despite how easy it should be to make such small apps. Most of these devs also have one or two large complex projects, made all by themselves. Note that these are *not* top users I saw on github, they're just the people I know from the Ruqqus dev chats!

https://ruqqus.com/post/244k/what-project-of-yours-are-you/714u

https://github.com/GingkathFox?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

https://github.com/Foxite?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language= and https://gitlab.com/users/foxite/projects

https://github.com/jakemayeux?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

https://github.com/Dog2puppy?tab=repositories&q=&type=source&language=

I started my first programming about 8 years ago in Java. It didn't get serious until about 4 years ago however, and a year after that I started C and C++.

I find it fun and enjoyable building things. Needless to say though, as much as I like it and do it a lot, I fucking suck, like I do at pretty much everything in life.

body:
Just press "C" on your keyboard and it'll come up. Press esc to close it and go back to the world.

Took me way too long to implement (several hours) but it's a huge improvement over the previous system where you had to type R G or B and enter the color value between 000 and 255.
body_html:
Just press "C" on your keyboard and it'll come up. Press esc to close it and go back to the world.

Took me way too long to implement (several hours) but it's a huge improvement over the previous system where you had to type R G or B and enter the color value between 000 and 255.

body:
If you've not heard of it before, it's my personal 3D paint/drawing game made using cubes instead of pixels. Check out this guild for more details. Below are some screenshots of the game:

![](https://i.imgur.com/CsTJFOc.png)

![](https://i.imgur.com/fGVsUsE.png)

[You can download it here if you're interested in trying it out](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/releases/tag/0.1). Everything is 64-bit, as no 32-bit computers are being made anymore and the existing ones probably can't run OpenGL 3.3 anyway.

No installation process is required, though you may need to install glfw3 and glew or whatever if you haven't yet (I didn't package them because they can be easily downloaded, and cygwin's dlls are the only ones I know are compatible with an MIT license). On the next release I'll try to link them statically so this won't be a problem.

The game should work on macOS too, but you'll have to [compile it from the source](https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/tree/0.1) to do that.

---

Unfortunately I couldn't get mods working on Windows. Apparently Windows has some weird requirements that doesn't let the linker ignore undefined symbols in *any* case, meaning the mods can't be compiled since they reference symbols from the main program. Technically the mod loader does work, it can load functions and I saw that it was able to execute the test mod, but to do anything useful it needs to be able to reference the main program. On other systems this is not a problem because symbols are allowed to be resolved at runtime.

I'd rather not use cygwin because it would be better to be able to compile native windows programs, but unfortunately mingw is giving me even more problems as it has a faulty implementation of <filesystem>, and I am not going to spend my entire life savings on buying Visual Studio right now.
body_html:
If you've not heard of it before, it's my personal 3D paint/drawing game made using cubes instead of pixels. Check out this guild for more details. Below are some screenshots of the game:

You can download it here if you're interested in trying it out. Everything is 64-bit, as no 32-bit computers are being made anymore and the existing ones probably can't run OpenGL 3.3 anyway.

No installation process is required, though you may need to install glfw3 and glew or whatever if you haven't yet (I didn't package them because they can be easily downloaded, and cygwin's dlls are the only ones I know are compatible with an MIT license). On the next release I'll try to link them statically so this won't be a problem.

The game should work on macOS too, but you'll have to compile it from the source to do that.

Unfortunately I couldn't get mods working on Windows. Apparently Windows has some weird requirements that doesn't let the linker ignore undefined symbols in any case, meaning the mods can't be compiled since they reference symbols from the main program. Technically the mod loader does work, it can load functions and I saw that it was able to execute the test mod, but to do anything useful it needs to be able to reference the main program. On other systems this is not a problem because symbols are allowed to be resolved at runtime.

I'd rather not use cygwin because it would be better to be able to compile native windows programs, but unfortunately mingw is giving me even more problems as it has a faulty implementation of <filesystem>, and I am not going to spend my entire life savings on buying Visual Studio right now.

guild.description: VoxelPlanet is a sandbox made out of colored cubes, using OpenGL and very basic shaders

https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/releases

Download these and click on the executable file, and install any missing dlls if necessary (probably glfw3 or glew). I wasn't sure whether they're okay to distribute.

There is no Mac version yet. I'll be happy to put one up but someone else will have to compile it. Sorry, but I am not spending all the money in the world buying a computer that can barely even do anything.
body_html:
https://github.com/CrystalVulpine/VoxelPlanet/releases

Download these and click on the executable file, and install any missing dlls if necessary (probably glfw3 or glew). I wasn't sure whether they're okay to distribute.

There is no Mac version yet. I'll be happy to put one up but someone else will have to compile it. Sorry, but I am not spending all the money in the world buying a computer that can barely even do anything.

body:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter *what*. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually *like* to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

* I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

* Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

* I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

* I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?
body_html:
I've about had it. I'm not even remotely good at one fucking thing, no matter how much I've done it or like it. No matter how much practice, no matter what. I don't know if I'm good at anything at all, but I know for a fact I'm not good at anything I actually like to do, so what's the point.

By "not good" I don't mean just not good, I don't mean just mediocre. I mean worse than a fucking novice could do. So yeah, can't do anything, can't have any hobbies at all.

Let's take a look at the things I do all the time yet have zero ability at:

  • I can't program hardly at all. If it takes me 2 fucking hours to figure out how to correctly loop through DOM elements after programming for > 4 years there's clearly no hope for me, in less time than that everyone else could build the framework for a complex algorithm.

  • Can't draw. I've gradually learned how to do things better but can't ever get any sense of perspective, and I'm extremely messy with my lines and stuff, and can only do basic coloring.

  • I'm not at all creative or imaginative anymore. I used to be somewhat, but not at all now. Even if I'm playing Minecraft or something I can never think of anything to do but build the most generic house or walk around the world aimlessly.

  • I suck at any kind of game, both real life games and video games. This includes ones I play a lot. Most people can always beat me even the first time they play.

It doesn't matter how much practice or focus or experience I have, I'm never ever improve. So I guess the only solution is that I'll never be able to do anything at all, so I'm quitting everything I like to do because I can't even do it.

I don't know where I'm going to go from here. I can't have any hobbies so Idk what to do with my time from now on. I suppose just sit around and watch tv and youtube all the time. I don't like that, but I guess I don't have a fucking choice.

Is there anything I can do?

body:
On the Ruqqus website itself, usually it's seen as a good thing to give constructive feedback on something. However in the Discord, most people practically worship the admins, and the mods too, and treat them like gods of Ruqqus or something. They're always the center of everything, and you don't dare oppose even one thing they do or else everyone gets in a hivemind and shits all over you for it. This is starting to look like the same kind of cult mentality that AHS has, and I don't think that's healthy for Ruqqus. I think some of the admins and mods are even starting to believe it and now think they're superior to others because of it, and that will undoubtedly lead to power abuse.

Anyone know why the discord users are doing this?
body_html:
On the Ruqqus website itself, usually it's seen as a good thing to give constructive feedback on something. However in the Discord, most people practically worship the admins, and the mods too, and treat them like gods of Ruqqus or something. They're always the center of everything, and you don't dare oppose even one thing they do or else everyone gets in a hivemind and shits all over you for it. This is starting to look like the same kind of cult mentality that AHS has, and I don't think that's healthy for Ruqqus. I think some of the admins and mods are even starting to believe it and now think they're superior to others because of it, and that will undoubtedly lead to power abuse.

Anyone know why the discord users are doing this?

guild.description:
For memes and shitposting about everything that happens in our beloved "Official Ruqqus Discord"
 
---

## Posting Rules


Rule 1: 

This guild is for shitposting about people/events in the Ruqqus Discord server. Any post that is not related to this will be kicked to +general. If you need help regarding the discord server, +askruqqus, +general, or +hub would gladly accept your questions.


Rule 2:

No spamming. Spamming would be considered any of the following:

* Same-format posting within a day

* Same-content posting within a day (Same content, different format)


Spammed posts will get kicked and repeated offenses results in being exiled.


Rule 3: 

No reposts: reposts are cringe. Any reposts will be kicked.

body:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely *zero* traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?
body_html:
I have a small problem where github is not letting anyone discover any of my repositories naturally. Most people I see get about 10-20 downloads per repo on average after a month or two, and get a small amount of traffic each day. This is typically done without any promotional efforts, so basically through the github algorithm and people discovering it through searching and exploring.

However, only one person other than me has ever downloaded something of mine, and according to the insights I'm getting absolutely zero traffic on any of my repos except for days I post about them on Ruqqus. This is not normal, so what could be the cause of it? Did github flag me as spam or something and suppress my repos from discovery channels? I did join less than a month ago and made a lot of contributions right off the bat, so maybe the servers think I'm a bot or something?
